title: 112_s3476
content: The Act may be cited as the "Improving Access to Child Care for Homeless Families Act of 2012". Child and youth homelessness has increased by 38 percent since 2006, with a 44 percent rise in homeless children served by Head Start programs. Among homeless children in HUD shelters, 50 percent are under 5 years old. A 2010 study found that high-quality care in early years leads to better academic and cognitive outcomes at age 19. Homelessness negatively impacts child development, leading to more instances of developmental delay, learning disabilities, and health problems compared to low-income peers in stable housing. Homeless families face obstacles like residential instability, mobility issues, documentation requirements, and lack of transportation when accessing child care services. Homeless families are also less likely to receive government financial assistance for child care. Without child care, homeless parents of young children struggle to search for employment, maintain employment, and enter job training programs. Many parents, including domestic violence survivors, are limited by a lack of child care, with 29 percent of domestic violence survivors in shelters indicating a need for help with child care. Congress should enact policies to increase homeless families' access to and continuity in child care, similar to successful policies for homeless children's access to education programs. Policies to increase homeless families' access to child care will help parents maintain employment, regain housing, and support vulnerable children. The purpose of this Act is to ensure access to high-quality child care for homeless children and families. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include social service programs in addition to child care and early childhood development programs. This expansion encompasses Head Start programs, services for vulnerable populations, and grants for entities providing related services. The Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 is amended to include services for homeless veterans under chapter 20 of title 38, United States Code, such as housing, employment-related services, and supportive services. The amendment includes provisions for homeless children to receive services under the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act, as well as the establishment of a grace period for compliance with health and safety requirements. Amendments include changes to subparagraph (H) and paragraph (3)(B) to improve access to services for homeless children and their families. The amendment aims to improve access to services for homeless children by ensuring that cost-sharing is not a barrier to enrollment. It also includes provisions for outreach and partnerships to provide transportation to child care services for families of homeless children. The amendment to the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 includes a new reporting requirement to determine if children receiving assistance are homeless. SEC. 5. PILOT PROGRAM. Amends the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990 to establish a new pilot program. The Secretary will conduct a pilot program to improve child care access for homeless children by awarding grants to States for implementing best practices. Each grant will not exceed $5,000,000 and will last up to 3 years. States must submit an application to be eligible for the grant and use the funds to establish pilot projects for enhancing child care access. The pilot program aims to increase child care access for homeless children by awarding grants to States to implement best practices. States must conduct data collection and assessments for their pilot projects, submitting a report to the Secretary within 42 months of the grant period. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress summarizing the assessments and best practices identified in the pilot projects within 4 years of the grant period. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2013 through 2015. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. Amends the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act to include a definition of a "homeless child" as defined under the McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act.
